answers: Cleisthenes <Other History, JP and AK><ed. AH>
parts: Name this statesman, who, with Aspasia, had a son who was executed following the unsuccessful Battle of Arginusae.
Pericles hailed from this Attic city, which was also home to the noted orator Demosthenes. This center of the Delian League often feuded with rival city-state Sparta.

This other Athenian statesman was the uncle of Pericles’ mother. Considered the father of Athenian democracy, he overthrew the tyrant Hippias and increased the size of the Council of 400 to 500 people.
Name this Jewish holiday that occurs on the 15th of Nisan, which commemorates the story of the Exodus with a ritual seder.
As the five leavened breads of the chametz are prohibited on Passover, this unleavened flatbread is consumed in its place.
Another ritual foodstuff consumed at the Passover seder are these bitter herbs which commemorate the bitterness of slavery in Egypt.

answers: Edward Kennedy “Duke” Ellington <Other Fine Arts, KLu><ed. OC>
parts: Name this song. A performance of this song concluded a 1938 Carnegie Hall performance by Benny Goodman’s band, and featured Gene Krupa on the drums.

“Sing, Sing, Sing” is a standard in this style of jazz, characterized by danceable rhythms and improvisation. Another song in this genre is titled “It Don't Mean a Thing (If It Ain't Got [this genre]).”
“It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing)” was composed by this jazz pianist. This man’s band often performed at the Cotton Club in New York City.
Name these organelles, whose main function is to break down their namesake molecule, H2O2, into oxygen and water.
This enzyme, which is contained in peroxisomes, is responsible for breaking down H2O2 into water and oxygen, as well as oxidizing compounds such as phenols and alcohols.
In this process, long-chain fatty acids are cleaved two carbons at a time, converting them into acetyl-CoA [["uh-SEAT-ill Co-A”]]. This process occurs in both mitochondria and peroxisomes.
Name this dark tone poem which uses a cor anglais to depict the title creature gliding and singing in the river of the underworld.
The Swan of Tuonela is part of Sibelius’s work Four Legends from the Kalevala, which depicts the mythology of this country of his origin.
Another famous swan in music is this princess who is captured by Baron von Rothbart in Tchaikovsky’s ballet Swan Lake.
This protagonist of Kafka’s The Trial seeks out Titorelli the painter for advice and is stabbed to death “like a dog” after being charged with an unknown crime.

During the trial of this Russian literary character, Katerina Ivanovna’s presentations shifts suspicion away from Smerdyakov. This brother of Ivan and Alyosha is then convicted of murdering his father.
Meursault is put on trial for shooting an Arab on a beach in this French-Algerian author’s novel The Stranger.
Perhaps the most famous Roman philosopher was this last of the Five Good Emperors, whose Meditations stand as a major work of stoic philosophy.

The Roman poet Lucretius was a notable popularizer of this philosophical school that became the leading opponent of stoicism, disagreeing on a number of key issues like political participation and free will.
A revival of this bean-hating philosopher’s teachings also emerged during the first century. He is better known for his mathematical theorem relating the lengths of a right triangle.

answers: iguana [accept The Night of the Iguana]
parts: Name this animal, which titles a play where Reverend T. Lawrence Shannon is accused of statutory rape while living in the Costa Verde Hotel run by Maxine Faulk.
This American playwright of The Rose Tattoo wrote The Night of the Iguana.
An old high school acquaintance named Jim O’Connor kisses Laura Wingfield at the end of this Williams play, which is named after Laura’s prized collection of miniature animals.
This painter of Domine, Quo Vadis founded an influential school of painting alongside his brothers Agostino and Ludovico.

The leader of the aforementioned cabal, Jose de Ribera, is often categorized as a follower of this rival Italian painter who painted The Calling of St. Matthew and The Conversion on the Road to Damascus.
Ribera imitated Caravaggio’s heavy use of this technique, the dramatic contrast of light and dark. Caravaggio used this technique to create a “spotlight” effect in his The Calling of St. Matthew.

answers: parity [or parity violation, prompt on P-conservation or P-violation]
anemia [accept megaloblastic anemia or pernicious anemia]
parts: The Wu experiment observed beta-decay in cobalt-60 to detect the violation of the conservation of this quantity.
Cobalt is also present in vitamin B12, a deficiency of which can cause the megaloblastic or pernicious types of this disease.
Cobalt is often used to make glass a deep shade of this color, which is also the color of copper sulfate.

answers: Bessie Mears [prompt on Mears] <Long Fiction, MX><ed. OC>
parts: Name this author, who wrote about an algebra teacher’s growing understanding of his heroin-addicted brother in “Sonny’s Blues.” He drew upon his experience as a preacher in his novel Go Tell it On the Mountain.
This contemporary and friend of Baldwin wrote about Bigger Thomas’ conviction after he accidentally smothers Mary Dalton in the novel Native Son.
In Native Son, Bigger rapes and kills this character by hitting her on the head with a brick and then throwing her into an air shaft.

answers: Butterfly Ballots <American History, AK and JP><ed. JB>
parts: Name this election decided following the Court’s ruling in Bush v. Gore.

This Justice publicly stated that a Gore Presidency would be a disaster. This first female Supreme Court Justice argued that affirmative action would be unnecessary in 25 years in her majority opinion in Grutter v. Bollinger.
One issue that added to the chaos in the election were these types of ballots that were issued in Palm Beach County, Florida. These insect-named ballots have been likened to a maze.
Name this thought experiment in which it is unknown whether the namesake animal is alive or dead.
Erwin Schrödinger also names an equation that states that the Hamiltonian acting on this thing is equal to the total energy times it. This function is symbolized psi [["sigh”]].
The Schrödinger equation is generally solved by making it independent of this variable. Because this quantity and energy are conjugate variables, there is an uncertainty principle relating them.

answers: Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia <Geography, AK><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: This prehistoric monument in Wiltshire, England has been a World Heritage Site since 1986. Some attribute this ring of standing stones as a Neolithic burial site.
In 2007, this country’s Arabian Oryx Sanctuary was removed from the list due to reduction of over 90% of the site’s area. This country includes the exclaves of Musandam and Madha.
The Rock Churches of Lalibela are one of nine World Heritage Sites in this country, which is tied for the most in Africa. This country shares Lake Turkana with Kenya.

answers: TIME <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, AK><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: Name this American entrepreneur who created his namesake “academy,” a free online education platform teaching a variety of academic subjects.
Khan was born in Metairie [[met-a-ree]], located in this US state. Another person of Indian descent from this state is Bobby Jindal, its former governor.
In 2012, this newsmagazine named Khan as one of its 100 most influential people in the world.
Name this Latin American independence leader who is considered a founding father to modern Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama.
This other Venezuelan revolutionary was widely regarded as a direct forerunner to Bolivar. In 1810, this man created the Supreme Junta of Caracas after deposing its colonial administrators.
Bolivar issued a letter from this island, in which he defended his principles. Samuel Sharp led a revolt on this island, which contained a pirate haven in its city of Port Royal.
Name this poet who described a place “where knowledge is free” in his collection Gitanjali.
In this Tagore poem, the speaker sits “on the river bank, sad and alone” and mournfully tells the title object “take away my golden paddy when you sail.”
Tagore’s “Jana Gana Mana” and his “Amar Shonar Bagla” became two works of this type. Francis Scott Key wrote a poem that later became one of these works.

answers: steric [accept steric factor or steric number] <Chemistry, CT><ed. KLei>
parts: Name this equation that relates the rate constant of a reaction to its activation energy and temperature. According to this equation, reaction rate will approximately double with every 10º C increase in temperature.
This number is raised to the power of “negative E sub a divided by RT” in the Arrhenius equation. It is approximately 2.718 and is the base of the natural logarithm.

In the Arrhenius equation, A is equal to the product of the collision frequency and a factor described by this word. A number described by this word is the number of bonds plus the number of lone pairs on a central atom.
Name this sore-covered god who self-immolated in order to become the current sun.
The previous age was ended by this type of natural disaster that nobody survived after Tezcatlipoca upset the goddess Chauchaulticue.
The role of the fourth sun was assumed by this “feathered-serpent” god of light and wind who created the current race of mankind.

answers: “Fifth Column” <European History, AK, JP, and DC><ed. AH>
parts: Name this man, who sent the Blue Division to fight for Nazi Germany on the Eastern Front during World War II. This dictator ruled his country under the title El Caudillo and came to prominence for his services in the Rif War.
Franco commanded a right-wing alliance of factions such as the Falangists and Carlists against left-wing Republicans in this war, in which American volunteers fought in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.
During the war, general Emilio Mola coined this term that denotes a traitorous group within a country. He proclaimed that groups given this term would undermine the Republican Spanish government.
